ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS? U. S.
Secretary-Treasurer's Office
Army Medical Museum
Washington, D. C.
18 April, 1928.
Hon. John M. Morin, Chariman,
Committee on Military Affairs,
House of Representatives, Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
In compliance with the desires of your committee as expressed at the hear-
ing on April 11, 1928, on the bill H. R. 11686 for the reward of those taking
part in the work of the Yellow Fever Board, I submit the following statement of
my connection with that work, and the names and status of those taking part in
it as requested of me by Hon. J. Mayhew Wainwright, who introduced the bill.

The Yellow Fever Board or Commission was organized and sent to Cuba by
the War Department upon the recommendation of Surgeon General Sternberg in June
1900, to study the cause and prevention of yellow fever, a matter whose vast
importance, I believe, the committee well understands.

The members of the Board were, Major Walter Reed, Surgeon, U. S. Army,
Acting Assistant Surgeons James Carroll, Aristides Agramonte and Jesse w.
Lazear, U. S. Army. A statement with regard to each of them is made below.

My connection with the work of this Board, which is of no great importance
except that it permitted me to be familiar with all the details connected with
their work and to furnish information which may be of value to your committee,
arose from the following circumstances:

I had gone to Cuba in 1898, with the Seventh Corps, of which General
Fitzhugh Lee was the Commanding General, and of which I became the Chief Sur-
geon. After the discharge of the volunteers in May, 1899, General Lee was
placed in charge of the military department of Western Cuba with headquarters
at Marianao. I was his Chief Surgeon with sanitary supervision of the area
under his command. The city of Havana was, however, excepted from his command,
being a separate military department under General Ludlow whose Chief Sanitary
officer was Major (afterward Major General) W. C. Gorgas. Major Reed and
Dr. Carroll arrived in Cuba June 25th, 1900;" the other two members of the
Commission, Dr. Agramonte and Dr. Lazear, being already on duty in Cuba. In
order to secure quarters and office room without expense and a healthy environ-
ment they received General Lee's permission to locate in certain buildings at
the hospital at Columbia Barracks, less than a mile from General Lee's head-
quarters. This location permitted me in my position to be of service to the
Commission in various ways, and I saw much of Major Reed, as we were old friends.
"At this time I was sick with yellow fever in the post hospital, Columbia Bks. &
Reed came out the day he landed to see me. I was thus the first case of yellow
fever that he ever saw.

It appears to me unnecessary to recount the dramatic and interesting story of the
work of the Board, as this is well covered in the first four chapters of Senate
Document 822, 61st Congress 3rd session entitled, “Yellow Fever, A Compilation of
Various Publications”, which the committee has resolved to have reprinted. It
will be sufficient to say that it may be divided into several phases.

The first was the demonstration that there was no foundation in the claim
of Sanarelli that the Bacillus Icteroides isolated by him was the cause of
yellow fever. This occupied the month of July. Then for sound epidemiological
reasons the Board determined to investigate the theory of Dr. Carlos Finlay
that yellow fever was transmitted by a certain variety of mosquito. This second
phase, including the successful incoulations of Carroll and Private Wm. H. Dean
and the tragic death of Dr. Lazear includes the period to October 12th when Reed,
accompanied by me had his interview with General Wood, which, by securing Gener-
al Wood's approval of experiments on human beings, and the grant of money for
necessary expenses, changed the whole character of the investigation. Reed then
went to the United States for a brief visit to consult with The Surgeon General
and read his paper, “The Etiology of Yellow Fever, A Preliminary Note”, at the
annual meeting of the American Public Health Association, October 22 to 26.
Upon his return to Cuba, October 28, begins the third phase of his work occupied
in the construction of an experimental station, camp Lazear, and the experiments
thereat upon American Volunteers and Spanish immigrants, which demonstrated the
method of the transmission of yellow fever and made clear the way of its preven-
tion. This phase may be considered to have been completed on February 4, 1901,
when Reed read before the Pan American Medical Association in Havana the report
of the Board, “The Etiology of Yellow Fever, An Additional Note”, giving the re-
sults of their experiments and their conclusions.

After the adjournment of this meeting Reed and Carroll returned to Washing-
ton, and Gorgas gave a practical application of Reed's conclusions by warfare
upon mosquitoes in the City of Havana in accordance with the 10th conclusion of
the Board which was:

“10.. The spread of yellow fever can be most effectually controlled by
measures directed to the destruction of mosquitoes, and the protection of the
sick against the bites of these insects.”

Dr. Carroll returned to Cuba during the Fall of 1901 to make certain other
experiments connected with the etiology of yellow fever by the injection of
filtered blood from cases of that disease which demonstrated that the organism
of the disease was a “filterable virus” which would pass through a pasteur por-
celain filter, and was therefore ultra-microscopic in the size. This completed
the fourth and last phase of the Board's work.

STATEMENT WITH REGARD TO THE CLAIMS OF THE PERSONS NAMED IN THE BILL WITH
PERTINENT DATA CONCERNING THEM. (First Category)

1. Mrs. Walter Reed was Emelie Lawrence of North Carolina. Her family came
originally from Massachusetts, and was related to the distinguished Bishop,
Right Rev. William Lawrence of Massachusetts. They were married in 1876. There
were two children of this marriage both of whom are living. Since the death of
Major Reed after an operation for appendicitis in Washington, November 23, 1902,
she was not remarried, and is a resident of the city of Washington.

At the time of his death the Secretary of War, the Hon. Elihu Root, had pro-
posed in his annual report to the President that Reed being the Senior Major in
his grade should be promoted to the grade of Colonel in the Medical Department
and that Major W. C. Gorgas should be promoted to the grade of Lieutenant Colonel.
This recommendation, although it had not been published, was known to the writer,
and Major Reed was told of it by him on his death bed. He replied, “I do not
care for that now.” The special promotion to Colonel was later given to Major
Gorgas.

With reference to the recognition of Reed's work by the United States
Government, Dr. Howard A. Kelly in his work “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever” quotes
at the beginning of Chapter X on the value of Dr. Reed's work to the world as
follows from the Bible, Book of Esther, VI - 3, "And the King said what homour
and dignity have been done to Mordecai for this? Then said the King's servants
who ministered unto him. There is nothing done for him.

The Surgeon General proposed that Major Reed's pay as Major ($291.00 per
month) be continued to Mrs. Reed as a pension. A bill providing for this was
introduced into the Senate by Senator Martin of Virginia, and was passed with
the amount reduced to $125.00 per month. A similar bill was introduced into the
House by Mr. Maynard of Virginia, and was referred to the Pension Committee, but
never reported out by them. On the morning of March 4, 1903, by agreement
between the Republican and Democratic leaders of the House, and the Speaker,
Mr. Henderson, the Pension Committee was discharged from consideration of the
bill and the Senate bill was taken up and passed. The appropriations for her
annuity were made for some years on the War Department appropriation bill, but
payments are now made by the Pension Bureau.

Regarding the value of Major Reed's services to this country and to humani-
ty, it is believed that the Committee is well informed. I would, therefore, only
quote a paragraph from a letter of Prof. William H. Welch of John Hopkins Uni-
versity written soon after Reed's death to the Secretary of War in which he
stated:

“Dr. Reed's researches in yellow fever are by far the most important contri-
butions to science which have ever come from an Army surgeon. In my judgment
they are the most valuable contributions to medicine and public hygiene which
have ever been made in this country with the exception of the discovery of
anaesthesia. They have led and will lead to the saving of thousands of lives.
I am in a position to know that the credit for the original ideas embodied in
this work belongs wholly to Maj. Reed.”

Major Reed left no property except a small life insurance, and the pension
received by Mrs. Reed is, as the Committee must realize, quite inadequate for a
comfortable and dignified existence. This inadequacy has been made worse by the
depreciation in the purchasing power of the dollar due to the World War, so that
her pension now is about equivalent to one of $75.00 at the time it was given.
It has been helped out to some extent by payment to her of the interest on a
fund collected by a group of Major Reed's friends for the purpose of erecting a
monument to him. The principal of this fund will be available to assist in the
erection of a monument to him whenever the Government sees fit to make provision
for one, provided that adequate support for Mrs. Reed has been made.

2. MRS. JAMES CARROLL - Mrs. Carroll was the wife of Dr. James Carroll by whom
she had seven children. Mrs. Carroll has, so far as is known to the writer,
never remarried. Her present adress is Box 2440, St. Petersburg, Florida. She
has received since soon after the death of Major Carroll on September 16, 1907,
a monthly pension of $125.00. Dr. Carroll was born in England and enlisted in
the army June 9th, 1874. He served in the grades of private, corporal, ser-
geant and hospital steward, first at Western posts and later in New York and
Washington. He took advantage of his opportunities as a medical department
soldier to study medicine and, being encouraged by the medical officers under
whom he served, graduated at the University of Maryland in 1891. He then, in
1893, became Major Reed's laboratory assistant at the Army Medical School in
Washington, where he served until his appointment as Acting Assistant Surgeon,
May 21, 1891. He served as Major Reed's assistant in the investigation of the
typhoid fever epidemic during the Spanish war, and, doubtless on his recommendation,
was made a member of the Yellow Fever Board in 1900. He permitted himself to be
bitten by infected mosquitoes, and was the first experimental case caused by the
Board, being taken sick August 31, 1900. In recognition of this experience he was
commissioned a first lieutenant and Assistant Surgeon in the medical corps,
October 27, 1902. From this grade he was promoted to Major by a special act of
Congress March 9, 1907. He died in Washington, D. C. of myocarditis Sept. 16, 1907.

Mrs. Carroll's pension has been, of course, inadequate for her needs and
those of her family. This inadequacy has been much increased by the fall in the
purchasing power of the dollar since the World War.

3. MRS. JESSE W. LAZEAR (Mabel M. Lazear) was the wife of Dr. Jesse W. Lazear,
Acting Assistant Surgeon, and third member of the Yellow Fever Board. At the
time of his death at Camp Columbia, Cuba, September 25, 1900, of yellow fever
incurred in the line of duty, they had two young children; the youngest of these
he never saw. She has not remarried and since his death has received an annuity
of $125.00 per month. It is understood that Dr. Lazear left very little property
and she had great difficulty in supporting herself and her children. Her present
address is, 6 Oak Vale Ave., Berkeley, California.

Jesse W. Lazear was born in Baltimore, May 2, 1866. He graduated in medi-
cine at Columbia University, New York City, in 1892, after which he served two
years at Bellevue hospital in New York. He then spent a year in Europe, a part
of it at the Pasteur Institute in Paris. On his return home he was made
bacteriologist to the medical staff of Johns Hopkins Hospital, and was also as-
sistant in clinical microscopy in the University. He was one of the first men
in this country to study the development of the malarial organism in the blood
of man and in the mosquito, and this knowledge was of the greatest value to the
Yellow Fever Board when they took up the study of that disease. He was a man
not only of brilliant professional attainments who but for his untimely death
would have gone far in his profession, but of nobel character and great personal
charm. He and his family have received no reward for his great services to the
country except the inadequate pension above mentioned, and the naming after him
of a Battery in Baltimore Harbor.

4. DR. ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE is the only living member of the Yellow Fever Com-
mission. He was born in Cuba during the Ten Years war, in which his father, a
Cuban officer, was killed in Battle by the Spaniards. The Agramonte family came
-5-
to New York when he was ten years old, and he grew up and was graduated in that
city. He graduated in medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons where
he and Lazear were class mates. At the beginning of the Spanish war he joined
the army as an Acting Assistant Surgeon, and after the American occupation had
charge of the Army Medical Laboratory in Havana. Upon the organization of the
Yellow Fever Commission he was detailed as a member of it, and contributed
materially to its success. He performed most of the autopsy work and the ex-
periments on animals, and after Lazear's death had charge of the mosquito work.
He served with the Army until the establishment of the Cuban Republic in May
1902. Upon the withdrawal of the American forces he remained in Havana and was
appointed a Professor in the Medical School of the University of Havana, a posi-
tion which he still occupies. During the American Government of Pacification in
Cuba, 1906-9 he was a member of the Yellow Fever Board in Havana, and rendered
valuable services in the campaign against yellow fever which had again broken
out in Havana and spread over most of the Island.

Dr. Agramonte has never received from the United States Government any honor,
recognition, or material reward for his distinguished services to this country
and to humanity as Member of the Yellow Fever Commission. The Cuban Government
has recently set us an example in generosity by voting a generous pension to the
widow of General Leonard Wood. It would seem that our country should in its turn
recognize its debt to Dr. Aristides Agramonte who, though now a Cuban, has worn
our uniform and rendered us distinguished service.
THE VOLUNTEERS WHO SUFFERED FROM EXPERIMENTAL YELLOW FEVER. (Second Category)

The second category of persons to whom the United States is indebted for the
conquest of yellow fever consist of fourteen names, twelve of whom were private
soldiers serving in Cuba. They are arranged in the bill in alphabetical order, and
will be considered in that order.

5. JOHN A. ANDRUS, Private, Hospital Corps, volunteered and was infected with
yellow fever by injection of blood at Camp Lazear, January 28, 1901. He was dis-
charged from the military service April 24, 1902, at Camp George H. Thomas,
Chickamaugua, Tenn. character excellent. He was born at Fassett, Pa. His
present address is not known. Father's address, Seth C. Andrus, Elmira, New York.
He received a donation of $200.00, paid by the writer" from Cuban funds granted by
the Military Governor, General Leonard Wook, but I understand does not receive
any pension from the United States.

6. MR. JOHN R. BULLARD was a native of Massachusetts and a graduate of Harvard
University where he was a distinguished athlete; he came to Cuba in 1901 where
he purchased land and engaged in farming. In the fall of 1901 he became ill with
malarial fever, and was brought to Camp Columbia for treatment. He was treated
by Dr. Carroll, who interested him in the yellow fever work, so that after his
recovery he offered himself as a volunteer for experiment. Dr. Carroll infected
him with yellow fever by the injection of blood, he being taken sick October 23,
1901. In point of time he was the Board's last experimental case. Mr. Bullard
has not, I believe, received any reward or recognition from the government of the
United States or the military government of Cuba. His present address is Ingenio
Jatibonico, Jatibonico P. O., Oriente, Cuba.
"Gen. TWood turned over this fund $10,000 to Major Kean for disbursement.

7. ALBERT W. COVINGTON, Private 23rd Company Coast Artillery was born at
Laurinsburg, N. C., enlisted at Maxton, N. C. He remained in the service until
August 9th, 1926, when he was retired for long service. Address Mrs. Rose
Covington, R. F. D. 3, Cohocton, New York.

He was one of the group of volunteers infected by Dr. Carroll by blood in-
jections in the fall of 1901. He received an injection of filtered blood serum
from a case of yellow fever, and became sick October 19, 1901. He received a
donation of $200.00 from the undersigned from the allotment of Cuban funds made
by General Wood for these experiments. He receives from the Government his re-
tired pay for long service, but no reward for his part in the yellow fever work.

8. WILLIAM H. DEAN, Private, Troop B, 7th Cavalry, was born at Holland, Ohio,
enlisted at Grand Rapids, Michigan, and was discharged Aug. 17, 1902. His
present address is unknown.

The case of this soldier, which followed that of Dr. Carroll, was of great
importance as it convinced Major Reed of the truth of Dr. Finlay's mosquito
transmission theory. He was infected on August 31, 1900, by the same mosquito
that had caused Dr. Carroll's illness, and on the same day that the diagnosis
of yellow fever in Dr. Carroll's case was made. His name was concealed at the
time under the anonymous designation “X.Y.” because the experiment was made with-
out military authorization at Columbia Barracks at a time when it was under rigid
quarantine against the introduction of yellow fever. He has never received any
reward from either the United States or from the Cuban Treasury.

9. WALLACE W. FORBES, Private, Hospital Corps, was born at Galesburk, Ill.; en-
listed at Minneapolis, Minn. He was discharged March 1, 1905, with character
excellent. The address of his mother whose name was not given on the record was
1523 Irving Ave., Minneapolis, Minn.

He volunteered to be infected with yellow fever by injection of blood at Camp
Lazear, and became sick January 24, 1901. He received a donation of $200 from
the Cuban funds allotted by General Wood for these experiments, but is not be-
lieved to have received any pension or other recognition from the United States.

10. LEVI E. FOLK, Private Hospital Corps, was born at Kadish, S. C.; he enlisted
at Columbia, S. C., and was retired for long service, March 30, 1923.

Folk was one of the men who volunteered to undergo the very trying experi-
ence of exposure to fomites by sleeping 20 nights in the bed clothing and body
clothes which had been used by yellow fever patients, and which was soiled with
their excretions.

It was obviously necessary to establish the fact that the men who underwent
this experiment were not immune, and Folk volunteered to be bitten by infected
mosquitoes, and was taken ill with yellow fever, January 23, 1901.

He received a donation of $100.00 for the fomites experiment and $200.00
for the yellow fever inoculation from the Cuban funds allotted by General Wood
for these experiments. He receives from the government his retired pay but has not,
so far is known, received any pension or other reward for his services as a
volunteer in these experiments. His present address is 374 S. 3rd Street,
Columbus, Ohio.

11. PAUL HAMANN, Private 23rd Company, Coast Artillery, was born in Germany and
enlisted at Springfield, Ill. After long service he was discharged August 12,
1913.

Hamann was one of the group of cases infected by Dr. Carroll in the fall of
1901 by injection of filtered blood serum from a case of yellow fever. He be-
came sick October 19, 1901.

He received a donation of $200.00 from the Cuban funds allotted by General
Wood for these experiments, and he receives from the Government a pension of
$20.00 per month. Address c/o his father, August Hamann, East Moline, Ill.

Hanberry, like Folk, first underwent the fomites experiment, and then vol-
unteered to be bitten by infected mosquitoes, and in consequence was taken sick
with yellow fever at Camp Lazear, February 9, 1901. He received donations
amounting to $300.00 from the Cuban funds allotted by General Wood for these ex-
periments.

Being a deserter he has, naturally, not received any pension or reward from
the U. S. Government.

13. MRS. WARREN G. JERNEGAN (N. May Jernegan) is the widow of Warren G. Jernegan,
Private, Hospital Corps, who was born at Cone, Florida. He was discharged at
Columbia Barracks, November 16, 1901, but afterwards was in the government em-
ployment at Panama, and, as stated by his widow, died February 5, 1919, while
still in government employ in Charleston, S. C.

He, like Folk and Hanberry, after undergoing the fomites experiment, volun-
teered to have his immunity tested by an injection of blood from a yellow fever
patient, and was taken sick January 8, 1901.

For these two experiments he received donations amounting to $300.00 from
the Cuban funds allotted by General Wood for these experiments. Mrs. Jernegan
receives a pension of $125.00 per month from the U. S. Government.

14. JOHN R. KISSINGER, Private, Hospital Corps, was born at McClure, Ohio. He
enlisted for the Spanish war at Indianapolis, Ind. He was discharged November
14, 1901, at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, with character excellent.

Kissinger with Moran, who will be next mentioned, were the first to volun-
teer as subjects for experiment in the second phase of the work of the Board.
Moran was first bitten, but Kissinger was the first to be infected and to suf-
fer an attack of yellow fever on December 8, 1900.

When promised a donation by Major Reed at the time he volunteered, Kissinger
declined it stating that he wished to undergo the experiment for the benefit of
science and humanity. After his recovery he was promoted to be Acting Hospital
Steward, and was presented with a gold watch by the Department Surgeon at a mili-
tary ceremony. This watch was paid for from the donation to which he was en-
titled, and he afterwards accepted the balance of the donation in money.

His health having failed he was on March 2, 1907, granted a pension of $12.00
per month. On Feb. 11, 1911, he was granted an annuity of $100.00 per month.
His present address is R. F. D. 146, Huntington, Ind.

15. MR. JOHN J. MORAN, was born in Ohio, and served as a volunteer in the
Spanish war in the 7th Army Corps. After his discharge he was employed by the
Army at the headquarters of General Fitzhugh Lee at Marianao as a clerk.

Mr. Moran disclaimed before submitting to the experiments any desire for
reward and has never accepted any, although he was offered the $200.00 from the
Cuban funds which the others received.

The first bites from infected mosquitoes received by him on November 26,
and 29 were, for some reason, unsuccessful. He was infected on the third
attempt on December 21, and came down with yellow fever on Christmas Day, 1900.

After leaving Cuba he completed his education by a course of study at the
University of Virginia, and then lived for a number of years in Panama in the
employ of the Isthmian Canal Commission. He is at present in Mexico and in the em-
ployment of the Firestone Tire Company, through which he can be communicated
with.

He has never received, nor, so far as is know, applied for any pension or
reward from either the Cuban Government or the Government of the U. S.

16. WILLIAM OLSEN, Private Hospital Corps, was born in Pierce County, Wis.;
enlisted for the Spanish war at Minneapolis, Minn., and was discharged Nov. 15,
1901, with character excellent, his address being given as 7211 San Pedro St.,
Los Angeles, California.

He was infected with yellow fever by injection of blood at Camp Lazear, and
taken sick January 11, 1901.

He received a donation of $200.00 from the Cuban funds allotted by General
Wood for these experiments. He is now in receipt of a pension from the Govern-
ment of $40.00 per month, presumably a Spanish war pension.

17. CHARLES C. SONNTAG, Private Hospital Corps, was born at Charleston, S. C. and
enlisted at Camp Onward, Ga. He was discharged Dec. 12, 1901, at Columbia
Barracks, with character very good.

He volunteered to be bitten by infected mosquitoes and was, in consequence,
taken sick with yellow fever at Camp Lazear, Feb. 10, 1901. He received a donation
of $200.00 from the Cuban funds allotted by General Wood for these experiments, and
is also at present in receipt of a pension of $50.00 per month. His present
address is R. R. #3, Gaston, S. C.

18. CLYDE L. WEST, Private, Hospital Corps, was born at Mier, Ind. and enlisted
for the Spanish war at Toledo, Ohio. He was discharged July 10, 1902, at Fort
Myer, Va., character, very good.

West volunteered to be bitten by infected mosquitoes at Camp Lazear, and was
-9-
taken sich with yellow fever Feb. 3, 1901. He received a donation of $200.00
from the Cuban funds allotted by General Wood for these experiments, also in
1927 was given a pension of $100.00 per month for his services as a volunteer
in the yellow fever work: he gets also a pension of $30.00 per month for his
Spanish war services.

p.hi: VOLUNTEERS IN FOMITES EXPERIMENTS; THIRD CATEGORY

div1.p:
19. DR. R. P. COOKE was born in Virginia in 1874. He volunteered for experi-
ment with fomites, and underwent the experiment with the first group who slept
in infected bedding. He had charge of all the men engaged in these experiments,
he entered the medical service of the army June 9, 1900 as a Contract Surgeon,
and was on duty in the hospital at Pinar Del Rio during the yellow fever epi-
demic at that place in July, 1900. He left the service at his own request Dec. 2,
1904. He received a donation of $100.00 from the Cuban funds allotted by Gener-
al Wood for these experiments, but has not received any recognition or pension
from the U. S. Government.

20. THOMAS M. ENGLAND, Private, Hospital Corps, was born in Chillicothé, Ohio,
and served in the army from January 6, 1899, to January 5, 1914, in the
grades of Private, Acting Hospital Steward, and Sergeant 1st Class Hospital Corps.
He again enlisted July 28, 1915, and served as Sergeant 1st class, and Hos-
pital Sergeant and Master Hospital Sergeant to February 15, 1918. He was then
appointed 1st Lieut. Sanitary Corps in the National Army and served until the

21. JAMES HILDEBRAND, Private, Hospital Corps, was born at Decatur, Ga. and en-
listed at Savannah, Ga., for service in Cuba. He was discharged August 17,
1914, at Walter Reed General Hospital, Washington, D. C., with character excellent.

Private Hildebrand underwent the fomites experiment, and then volunteered to
be bitten with infected mosquitoes. He was, however, rejected by Major Reed for
this experiment on account of his age, being over 40 years old. It is well known
that yellow fever is much more fatal at that age and later than with young men.

He received a donation of $100.00 from Cuban funds allotted by General Wood
for these experiments. He is now in receipt of a pension from the United States
of $50.00 per month, which it is understood is given him on account of long serv-
ice and ill health, and not for his participation in these experiments.
His present address is 412 Berean Street, Atlanta, Ga.

22. EDWARD WEATHERWALKS, Private, Hospital Corps, was born at Pompton, N. J.,
and enlisted for service in Cuba at Savannah, Ga., and was discharged February
12, 1901, at Columbia Barracks with character good.

He underwent the fomites experiment and was bitten once by mosquitoes with-
out becoming infected. He afterwards declined further experiments. He received

He died October 21, 1916, at Haskell, N. J. His widow, Mrs. Lucy Weatherwalks,
lives at Lenox Ave., Pompton Lake, N. J., and receives a pension of $30,00 per
month, presumably on account of her husband's service in the Spanish War.

In addition to the American volunteers enumberated above there were 7 Spanish
immigrants who were employed to undergo these experiments. Their engagement to
do so was a purely business arrangement which was approved by the Spanish Consul
at Havana; a signed contract was entered into with each one. These men who had
come to cuba to get employment realized well the danger of death by yellow fever,
and it was explained to them that in undergoing these experiments they would have
the best medical care and nursing, and would be paid what was to them a very
large sum of money, $200.00 American gold at the then rate of exchange being
worth about 1300 Spanish pesetas. The names of these men are as follows:

A wide distinction should, in my mind, be made between the payments to the
Spanish peasants employed by the Board and the donations made to the American
soldiers who volunteered to take part in the experiments. In the latter case
the payment was regarded as a gratuity which was given in recognition of their
meritorious services in the same way that the increased pay was given to men
who had earned a certificate of merit by gallantry in action. The only interest
which the Spaniards took in the matter was to acquire immunity with the slight-
est possible risk, and to get a handsome payment for their services. The
Americans on the contrary understood what it was all about and were tremenduous-
ly interested in the importance to humanity of a successful result.
